item.title: I forget what Amsterdam sounds like sometimes
item.description: Nothing ungovernable, it’s more like a hum. The hum of I’m not feeling at my best, of can’t get that argument out of my head, of what if, what if, what if; a hum that I eventually forget is there at all, even though it never ceases to soundtrack my every move.

item.title: How I rate
item.description: Over the weekend, I fleshed out this website’s library; a page that will hopefully soon be a living overview of all the media and culture I consume.

item.title: Where I'm struggling
item.description: The procrastinating part of me celebrates these words. I want a good calendar app. One I’m excited to use, that works across devices, and is happy with multiple accounts that didn’t all originate in its own ecosystem.

item.title: Eating with hands
item.description: They open their roti takeout, unfold their pancake, and start eating. Strike a pose, there’s nothing to it. I ask them if it’s okay that I watch them eat before I start, so I can see how in the world I’m supposed to eat sauce without cutlery.

item.title: IndieWeb Carnival: Tools
item.description: Remember Flickr, and the way we self-published visual sneak peeks into our lives on that website, in the mid-zeroes? If we wanted a filter in our photo, we had to Photoshop it in there ourselves.

item.title: Present in action, without speculation
item.description: My pastors have a way with words. Bible study on Thursday, and we use every pronoun but he reading Mark 6:1-13. She’s just a carpenter — Mary’s girl. Who does she think she is? Give me a second, let me hear that again.

item.title: Proclamation
item.description: Whenever a person interviews me, because it always takes the form of an interview, about why I identify as a Christian despite, well, everything, I never quite know what to tell them. Whatever eloquence I ascribe to my person vanishes at the sound of all the words in the known universe failing to capture what it means when I say I follow Jesus. Cringe.

item.title: Five recent UX uses for AI
item.description: There’s a reason I keep thinking Millennials are the new Boomers, and that reason is me. Here are some thoughts on how I finally came to welcome AI as a friendly member of my UX toolkit.

item.description: Isn’t it one of God’s cruelest jokes, Manuele, our ability to feel imposter syndrome? When I read your post — late, obviously, because RSS feeds and I will never quite be best friends — I was struck by your openness on the matter.

item.title: Accessibility on the small web
item.description: The March edition of the IndieWeb Carnival is about accessibility on the small web. The host, orchids, touches on a note-worthy design pattern found in this fine corner of the Internet: that of artsy, personal websites that emulate technology of old, particularly the early days of Internet.

item.title: Terms of inclusion, short and long
item.description: My coworker Mattia is a gem; a man of deep thought and good ideas. He asked me today if I knew of any writing on the topic of language learning and inclusion.

item.title: The surfer
item.description: The surfer, she tells me she met a woman at a 40s singles mixer. The type of woman who reschedules her flight home to Colorado so that they can have sushi in California.

item.title: Vibe check no. 1
item.description: Introduction For years, years I tell ya, I’ve been telling myself I need to write better week notes. “Better” refers to their frequency and to a lesser extent to their content.

item.title: Defaults: early 2024 edition
item.description: Inspired by App Defaults, this is a list of the main tools I frequently use these days. Type App(s) Experience Mail client Spark 🙂 Mail server Various 😑 Notes Obsidian 😏 To do Goodnotes 😏 Photo shooting Camera.

item.title: Flutter
item.description: There’s a weekend-long dance workshop in town. While she’s certainly not our first house guest, the situation feels brand new. It must be the Japanese mattress we just bought, which turns our one-bedroom shoebox of an apartment into a temporary bed and breakfast (and lunch and dinner) for Anneli, the journalist from Sweden.

item.title: Week 3: Beaming
item.description: In the evenings, we’re continue our journey with Better Call Saul (2015-2022). Midway through season 3, it’s finally beginning to get a firm grip on our attention span again.

item.title: Week 2: Omek
item.description: This week marked the week I got back into the swing of things at work. I tend to find the holiday season quite boring because things slow down quite a bit.

item.title: Week 1: Miracle mornings
item.description: A somewhat quiet week, mostly spent at the office because Anja’s on winter break, although I did enjoy spending time at Coffee Company Oosterdok as well.

item.title: Annual review at 36
item.description: In one way or another, the number 36 has felt like a milestone birthday for a long time. As a tween, I imagined the glamorous autonomy that came with being 36 because I was hooked on watching the televised adventures of a foursome of privileged White women in Manhattan.

item.title: A lifetime without representation
item.description: My friend and I reunite after 18 months. I missed him dearly, but once we sit down for ramen we can both tell it’s like we were there yesterday.

item.title: Now
item.description: This is an archived now page, which I created in December 2023. There I am at Coffee Company Oosterdok, pondering what I’ll have for lunch.

item.title: Week 47: Geert Milders
item.description: Covid It’s curious to see my response to a bout of Covid is not much different from what it was in early 2020.

item.title: Week 46: Osama
item.description: I’m making an attempt this week to make my weeknotes more of a personal record rather than a performance of how exciting my week is.

item.title: The artificial borders of climate activism
item.description: Yesterday at the Climate March, someone shouted “From the river to the sea, Palestine will be free”. It was an unfortunate thing.

item.title: Sermon
item.description: I delivered this sermon today at All Saints Amsterdam. A few months ago, along with much of humanity, it seemed, I went to see Barbie.

item.title: Week 39: Small escapes
item.description: First of all: not a great week. I continue to struggle to notice when I feel stresed or overwhelmed, and it never fails to result in my body giving me a clear sign.

item.title: Film club S01E01
item.description: Yesterday, I attended the very first gathering of FC de Filmfanaten, a brand-new film club that my friend Jolien started. There were four of us, and we discussed the movie I was proud to have suggested: Talk To Me.

item.title: Week 37: Rosh Hashanah
item.description: Cooler temperatures! After the hottest week I’ve experienced in months, things were back to comfortable Summer weather. By the time I’m writing this the sky is gray and it’s raining, but this week’s weather was cheerful and moderate.

item.title: Week 36: Homecoming
item.description: IT IS HOT STOP CLIMATE CHANGE NOW. I don’t think I’ve seen hotter days this year than week 36. Getting out of a hot shower and feeling equally wet fifteen minutes later.

item.title: Two things true
item.description: I saw a guy on Monday that I went on a date with once. It was one of those whimsical dates.

item.title: Week 34: Somerlust
item.description: Met Tim Bleeker at Somerlust Park on Tuesday, a get-together that started as “chilling in the park”, and which turned into grabbing a drink at l’Osteria.

item.title: Week 33: Landing
item.description: The first week back at work is fairly quiet, I even found myself on the verge of boredom at one point.

item.title: Norway et al
item.description: After two weeks in Scandinavia, it’s clear: we are both too Dutch for proper recycling. Secretly hoarding our trash to avoid a reprimanding from our AirBnb host as he hovers over his six-compartment recycling bin, we continue our trip from rural Sweden to Copenhagen looking for a public recycling station.

item.title: So, about this Scriptogr.am
item.description: I am notorious for never grasping how many people know how much about what. To save myself from any further embarrassment I won’t spend my time here telling you what the app is about.

item.title: What Pride means to me in 2023
item.description: Nienke, Mehdi, an anonymous friend, and I attend the annual Pride March. It’s the city’s first two-week Pride festival in Amsterdam, each week organized by a different organization.

item.title: Week 27: Haven
item.description: This week, I attended my first Gerimedica party. It’s great to know I can expect a big celebration every year, and not just for the company’s sweet sixteen.

item.title: Week 26: Keti Koti
item.description: Two months of onboarding have rushed by in a blink. The new job is absolutely wonderful: the people are great, the work is complex and important, and the office itself is perhaps the finest I’ve ever worked at.

item.title: We all live in a white submersible
item.description: I love a good media drama. Like a moth to a flame, or perhaps more accurately like a fly to dog poo, I am drawn to it.

item.description: Every time I embark on a journey towards a published post about why it’s good to have a website, I get lost in the reality of personal details.

item.title: Maker's marks for King's Day
item.description: It’s late in the morning and I’m on my way to Gerimedica, the company’s I’m excited to be joining in May, which is next week already.

item.title: Come back to Chigaco
item.description: Spring is here, I think? I spend the afternoon in the park with ex-colleague-turned-friend Susan, who is celebrating landing a new and challenging job.

item.description: Today, Lemonade and I visited Studio Pansa Amstel, where Anja has spent the last seven Sundays learning how to work a ceramics wheel.

item.title: Meeting Yana and DJ
item.description: What I love most about today’s snapshot is the despair I can see in Lemonade’s eyes even when her entire body is a background blur.

item.title: The cat
item.description: Life sure is different now that we’ve gotten Lemonade on a proper walking schedule. She still feels most comfortable going potty on the puppy pads we have on our balcony, but she absolutely loves going out and exploring the neighborhood.

item.title: Eight of ten
item.description: When I first set foot in the Old Catholic Church to attend an All Saints service, I knew I had found a special place.

item.title: A very Mathilde visit
item.description: Much like last year, I’m so excited for Mathilde to visit our house that I get a headache just thinking about it.

item.title: Showing up not knowing what will happen
item.description: I met Shervin at the coffee place this morning. We know each other very casually; we used to frequent the same co-working space, we’re LinkedIn friends.

item.title: Week 11: Meeting Patrick
item.description: I got to meet one of my Internet heroes this week: Patrick Rhone and his family were on a Europe trip, and I was lucky enough to catch the planning stage on his blog right in time to extend an invitation.

item.title: A phone call with an old friend
item.description: Happiness today is the ease with which the nun gives me his phone number. Paul is an old friend, or really an old friend of my ex, and we haven’t spoken in eight years.

item.title: Week 10: Outings
item.description: It snowed a few times this week and I was as baffled as I always am to see it happening in March.

item.title: Two weeks with a dog
item.description: Lemonade, Lemonade, Lemonade. Who knew I would ever become a dog person? Two weeks ago, we picked up our corgi Lemonade Zelda Loulé.

item.title: All Saints Amsterdam
item.description: She blesses Anja, me, and a handful of other people who carved out time in their Sunday evenings to come to Church.

item.title: Saturday morning routines
item.description: Living in a good neighborhood has many advantages. One of them is that it makes me want to spend a lot of time there.

item.title: Walking with Annelie
item.description: Walking with Annelie is coffee indoors today. We’ve told each other we need to go on more walks. She asks if we should dress warmly for the cold, wet park, or if we should just grab a table inside.

item.title: That was January 2023
item.description: January flew, flew by, I tell you. We started with “wow, 2023 already, let’s have a chill time this year, hey what’s on Netflix?

item.description: My attempt to lure both Anja and myself outside for some fresh air and a walk was thwarted as soon as I learned the place was out of my favorite bubble tea.

item.description: We had two friends over today. They’re dear to me specifically because we got to know each other intimately during our eating disorder recovery.

item.title: Super-recognizer
item.description: On occasion, Anja will compliment me on my ability to recognize people. I don’t know when I first noticed it myself, but there are actors I recognize even if they played minor characters in an episode of a show I watched 15 years ago.

item.title: Prospective dog owners
item.description: I’m in that supremely annoying stage of prospective dog ownership where I casually interrogate dog owners at parties, curious about their pet’s behavior and the techniques employed, and then silently judge them for their mistakes, exchanging contemptuous glances with Anja in the process.

item.description: This morning I got acquainted with the immigrant anxiety felt by Chinese-American journalist Jiayang Fan about her desire to speak accentless English.

item.description: Sometimes, when bad news arrives, I think to myself “argh, just when I was beginning to think life was nice and steady!

item.title: The art of music theory
item.description: In a few days, I’ll hit my one-month mark on the piano. When I bought it and began playing, I made sure to keep an open mind about how I learn best; not following any particular method, but tailoring practices to my interests, speed, challenges, and desires.

item.title: `alt` text culture
item.description: More than any other time in my online life am I aware of the value of alt text. I make a point to write image descriptions whenever I can.

item.title: Everything about the dog
item.description: Have you heard? Anja and I are getting a dog. It was up in the air for a little while, but we got the confirmation yesterday that we’ll get first pick of a nest of eight adorable little Pembroke - Cardigan corgi mixes.

item.description: Happy Hanukkah and/or Christmas to those who celebrate! Even though our house is (reluctantly) multi-religious, we forgot just about every tradition we were ever taught for this time of the year.

item.title: Week 47: Booster
item.description: I forgot how the COVID booster can make you feel as though, temporarily, the world may well be ending. I got it earlier this week, and it left me with a sore arm and that dreadful, ridiculous sensation that accompanies a flu that lasts a week too long.

item.title: Notes on my web mastery
item.description: Recently, I’ve been making some great progress with my personal website. While I normally don’t engage in technical ballets on the goings-on of this website, I feel it’s relevant to document what I’ve learnt and done, if only for posterity.

item.title: Week 44: Coat
item.description: The weather has officially reached a temperature that requires me to buy a new coat. I dread it. Unlike most other types of clothing, coats and jackets never seem to suit me, regardless of the style.

item.title: Week 16: Springtime holidays
item.description: Each year I’m less embarrassed to say it: I don’t like that stretch of time during the Dutch Springtime when no work week is normal.

item.description: Brushing my teeth on Friday morning, I think about the weekend ahead, secretly complaining that my social engagements will keep me from getting the rest I need.

item.title: Week 13: Recruiting
item.description: It has been snowing in Amsterdam. As the years go by, I’m having trouble understanding whether I’m experiencing the effects of global warming, or whether I’ve never paid attention to what was always in front of me until now.

item.title: How to be Black
item.description: Steer clear of Adidas; obtain a degree in Dutch language and literature; wear my aunt’s glasses until I eventually need my own prescription; don’t eat fried chicken; proclaim I’m a fan of Michel Houellebecq; don’t go to a black hair salon; enrol in theological seminary; don’t listen to RnB; date a person blacker than me; date a person whiter than me; don’t eat watermelon; say I’m ‘accidentally black’ because my mother met my father while on vacation and I missed by only an inch the opportunity to be born to a white father who was a doctor, by the way; eat bananas only after I cut them into bite-size chunks that I eat with a fork, just to make sure I don’t remind anyone of a monkey; don’t listen to rap music; learn difficult words.
